content.story_title: RMF: Federal Standard para Risk Management
content.story_intro: NIST SP 800-37. Mandatory para federal agencies. Adoptado por private sector.

steps.title: Step 1: Categorize
steps.content: Categorize information system y data según impact (Low, Moderate, High). FIPS 199 criteria: Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability. Determines baseline controls.
steps.insight: Healthcare data = High. Email system = Moderate. Public website = Low. Categorization drives everything.

steps.title: Step 2: Select
steps.content: Select security controls from NIST SP 800-53. Baselines: Low (100+ controls), Moderate (200+), High (300+). Tailor to org needs. Cost-benefit analysis.
steps.insight: Don't implement all controls blindly. Tailor to threats, resources, mission. Document rationale.

steps.title: Step 3: Implement
steps.content: Implement selected controls. Document HOW implemented. Configuration, procedures, training. Evidence collection for assessment.
steps.insight: Implementation ≠ checking box. Must be effective, documented, maintainable. Equifax: Had controls on paper pero no enforced.

steps.title: Step 4: Assess
steps.content: Independent assessor evaluates control effectiveness. Testing: Interviews, documentation review, technical testing. Identify deficiencies. Risk assessment report.
steps.insight: Independent assessment critical. Self-assessment = bias. Third party finds gaps you miss.

steps.title: Step 5: Authorize
steps.content: Authorizing Official (AO) reviews assessment. Accept residual risk? Sign Authority to Operate (ATO). Valid 3 years typically. Conditions may apply.
steps.insight: AO accountable for risk. Can reject if too high. ATO = permission to operate with known risks.

steps.title: Step 6: Monitor
steps.content: Continuous monitoring. Vulnerability scans, log review, config checks. Annual assessment. Report changes. Maintain ATO.
steps.insight: Security is NOT one-time. Continuous monitoring = maintain ATO. Equifax: Monitoring failed (expired cert).

back.definition: Limit system access to authorized users. Least privilege, separation of duties, account management, access enforcement, remote access controls.
back.example: AC-2: Account Management. AC-3: Access Enforcement. AC-6: Least Privilege. Equifax: Over-privileged accounts may have contributed.

back.definition: Detect, report, correct flaws. Malware protection, monitoring, vulnerability management. SI-2: Flaw Remediation (patching).
back.example: SI-2: Equifax FAILED. Patch available, not applied. SI-4: System Monitoring. Expired cert = monitoring failure.

back.definition: Periodic risk assessment. Vulnerability scanning, threat modeling, impact analysis. RA-3: Risk Assessment, RA-5: Vulnerability Monitoring.
back.example: RA-5: Vulnerability scans. Equifax had scans pero no remediation. Assessment without action = useless.

back.definition: Incident handling capability. Preparation, detection, analysis, containment, eradication, recovery. IR-4: Incident Handling.
back.example: IR-6: Incident Reporting. Equifax delayed public disclosure = violation de timely reporting best practice.

unlock_content.title: Asset & Threat Identification
points: Assets: Hardware, software, data, people, facilities
Criticality: Mission-critical, important, routine
Threats: Natural (flood), human (hacker), environmental (fire)
Threat actors: Nation-state, criminals, insiders, hacktivists
Equifax: Crown jewels = 147M records. Threat = financially motivated attackers
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Asset valuation: Replacement cost + data value + business impact. Crown jewels deserve most protection.

unlock_content.title: Vulnerability Assessment
points: Technical: Unpatched software, misconfigurations, weak passwords
Physical: Unlocked doors, lack of cameras
Administrative: Poor policies, lack of training
Discovery: Vulnerability scans, penetration testing, audits
Equifax vulnerabilities: Unpatched Struts, no segmentation, monitoring gaps
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Vulnerability ≠ risk. Risk = Vulnerability × Threat × Impact. All three factors matter.

unlock_content.title: Risk Analysis
points: Qualitative: High/Medium/Low. Faster, subjective.
Quantitative: ALE (Annual Loss Expectancy) = SLE × ARO. Slower, objective.
Risk matrix: Plot likelihood vs impact
Inherent risk: Before controls. Residual risk: After controls.
Equifax: Inherent risk HIGH (CVSS 10.0). Residual risk STILL HIGH (no patch).
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Quantitative example: SLE=$10M (breach cost), ARO=0.2 (20% chance/year) = ALE=$2M. Worth spending $500K on controls?

unlock_content.title: Risk Register
points: Risk register: Centralized log of all identified risks
For each risk: Description, likelihood, impact, mitigation, owner, status
Heat map: Visual representation for executives
Update frequency: Quarterly or when significant changes
Escalation: Board-level risks reported to board
Equifax: Risk register should have flagged Struts as critical
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Good risk register is LIVING document. Not create once and forget. Regular reviews mandatory.

content.question: NIST RMF Step que Equifax falló primarily?

options.feedback: Incorrecto. Equifax likely categorizó data correctamente (High). Problem no fue categorization.

options.text: Implement & Monitor (Steps 3 & 6): Controls documented pero no enforced/monitored
options.feedback: CORRECTO! Step 3 (Implement): SI-2 (Flaw Remediation) existía on paper pero patch process BROKE. Implementation inefectiva. Step 6 (Monitor): Continuous monitoring falló. SSL cert expiró = couldn't monitor traffic. Vulnerability scans no triggered action. Monitor controls (SI-4) failed. Lesson: Having control ≠ control working. Must verify effectiveness continuously. Authorization (Step 5) should have been revoked when monitoring failed.
Incorrecto. Equifax likely selected appropriate controls (SI-2, SI-4). Selection wasn't problem - execution was.
Partially. Independent assessment might have caught gaps pero primary failure: Implementation & Monitoring.
